div.p:
I promised you my dear Miss Robinson in what-
-ever part of the World I might chance to reside, that I would
give you some account of the manners of the people I lived
amongst & that I would communicate to you all my
observations I had an opportunity of making on the
peculiarities either of the climate; soil; &c. I have delay
-ed delayed performing my promise, neither through indolence
or forgetfulness but in order to acquire more certain infor-
-mation information & so collect facts worth telling you ---
The Irish are perhaps the laziest civilized nation on the
face of the earth; to avoid a moment's present trouble, they
will bring on themselves real misfortunes; When urged by
necessity (for without that spur they never exert themselves)
they work with excessive violence for a short space of time & then
sink again into a species of torpid Inaction - for this indo-
-lence indolence peculiar to the Irish Peasantry, several causes may
be assigned; amongst others the most powerful is the low
wages of labor, 6d. a day in Winter and 8d. in Summer; the
demand for labor must be very little, indeed, in a country
when the day labourers in it, can find it answer to go over
to a foreign Nation, in search of Employment: this is actu-
ally actually the case among the Irish Peasantry; they go over to
England during the harvest there, which comes on much
sooner than that in Ireland, to get work & higher wages than
they can earn at home - Every day labourer has about
three acres of land, sown with potatoes enough to afford a
bare subsistence to him & his wretched family - he does not
covet or even seem to relish the luxuries or the conveni-
-ences conveniences of life; they live in a huts whose mud built walls can
scarcely support their weather-beaten roofs: you may see the
children playing before the cabins sans shoes, sans stockings,
sans everything - the father of the family on a fine summers
day standing in the sunshine at his door while his house
is ready to fall upon his head & is supported only by two
or three props of wood; perhaps out of charity you go up to
him, & tell him that he had much better set about repair-
-ing repairing his house. - he would answer you Oh (pronounced Ho)
faith." Honey when it falls it will be time enough to
think of picking it up." - their Cabins have no chimneys
so that it is no wonder they lose their eye-sight by living
in such a cloud of smoke, it is remarkable that there are
more blind people among the lower class of Irish than among
any other set of men: the Common people are exceedingly
fond of spiritous liquors; Whiskey is their favorite, this is
a liquor distilled from potatoes: the distillers think of promo-
-ting promoting the exportation of it; nothing would more effectually or
more immediately tend to the encouragement of Agricul-
-ture agriculture , or be a stronger incitement to the lower class of people
to become industrious - it is not to suppose that idleness
is inherent in the Irish; no, they only want motive, give
them motive & they will exert themselves; but not till then -
if we look back into the history of England for we shall
find that the English were once as indolent a nation as the
Irish are at present. Every Nation has passed this Stage
in their progress to civilization;
I except the
Ameri-
-cans Americans
, for they went over
from Europe took
with them the manners, the acts, the improvements
of the European Nations consequently they did not go gra-
-dually gradually through all the different stages of Civilization they
came "ready armed from the head of Jupiter" - to con-
-clude conclude their character, the Irish are, remarkably hospita-
-ble hospitable to strangers; friendly, & charitable to each other; a pro-
-pos propos , about charity, I must observe to you that the charity
of the Higher class of people in Ireland is one of the greatest
checks to industry, it encourages Idleness amongst
the Poor, & increases, through it the numbers, or rather
the swarms of Beggars, which infest the streets of Dublin Let the rich raise the wages of Labor, the rewards of in-
-dustry industry , that would be true charity - - - - - - - - - - -
The lower class of irish are extreamly eloquent, they have
a volubility, a fluency & a facility of delivery which is
really surprizing, they use a great deal of action; & they
are good lawyers - they are obliged from not following any
settled employment to have recourse to various means
of procuring a livelihood, necessity obliges them to exercise
their understandings, but they in general turn their
abilities to the purposes of fraud & artifice -
The irish Irish language is now almost gone into disuse, the
lower class of People all speak English; except in their quar-
-rels quarrels with each other; then unable to give vent to their rage
in any language, much more in any but their own they
have recourse to that & they throw it out with a rapidity
and vehemence which I can give you no idea of - it is a
remarkably harmonious language, but it is spoken with
an accent (or as it has been styled Brogue) which is extream-
-ly extremely grating to a foreign Ear - The Irish claim their origin from
the Phoenicians; I will tell you a fact which favors this
supposition; Plautus who wrote, I think in the time of
Tiber1us Cesar introduces in one of his plays a phoeni-
-cian Phoenician slave, who speaks a strange language, which none
of Plautus's translators could make any thing of: this language
which the Phoenician slave spoke, has since been discovered to
be the same as that
which is now called Irish -
There are finer lakes in this Country, I had almost said, than you
can have any idea of the face of the country is disfigured with
large tracts of Bog. it is supposed that these bogs were originally
formed by the leaves & bark of immense forests of trees. which
A peasant who was working in a bog belonging to
my Father, found several feet below the surface a man's coat
a basket full of arrows & a wooden bowl, with several other
wooden utensils; the coat was neither knit or wove, it was of
a manufacture now quite unknown, my father has sent it
over to the Royal Society - I mention this circumstance to prove
that Ireland was inhabited previous to the formation of
the Bogs; by what strange fatality it became desolate, & how
it became again inhabited, by the Savages the English found
here on their first descent upon this Island? are very intricate
ques problems, something similar to the famous question
How America became first inhabited by the Savages the
Europeans found there? - the North of Ireland is much better
cultivated than the other parts; a spirit of Industry reigns
amongst the Inhabitants; this has probably been imparted to
them by their intercourse with that hardy, laborious people
the Scotch - I must reserve any particulars relative to the
state of politics in Ireland &c till my next:- if you wish to know
any more about this Nation, or the Scotch, of whom I have not
hitherto spoken - - - - - - - - - -

You will think, my dear Fanny that my I change my
employments, my tastes, my pursuits every four months; or
that Proteus-like I assume different shapes; indeed from my letters
you would have some reason to suppose it; in one letter you find
me enchanted with the hills & dales & woods of Surrey, in my next
you ask me to send you a tale to amuse you, & lo! you receive
a dialogue on happiness; "I asked for bread & she gave me a stone"
In a third you find me immersed in Politics, amongst old
newspapers, older pamphlets, Blackstone's commentaries, Burgh's
political disquisitions, de Lolme on the Constitution of England
&c &c &c. writing Enquiries into the coures of the poverty of Ireland"
(which by the bye I will send you when I have an opportunity) Essays
&c . . . - such were my employments when I wrote to you last,
but if you were to know what I am now about! . . . - but I will
(I mean if I can) keep my own secret . . .
I received your very pretty present safe; the two figures are both
graceful & pleasing; I think Mr. Robinson particularly excells in
the drapery: if I could venture to point out a little defect in
this little elegant piece it would be that the Mother's countenance
is not sufficiently expressive of the pathetic; the young Woman's
is as it ought to be, strongly expressive of sweetness & gentleness mix
-ed with grief. You know my dear Miss Robinson that I am no
painter myself & therefore I am afraid you will think me >pre-
-sumptuous presumptuous in pointing out the only defect that could be fixed up-
-on upon in your Brother's Mr. Robinson's very pretty performance, by
way of course, the only one I can plead, I must recall to your re-
-membrance remembrance a little anecdote which you doubtless have met
with - A Shoe maker, went to see one of Apelles's paintings
& overlooking the superior excellence of the piece he observed
that the shoe was very ill done - - - I assure
you, I shall have the print framed & hang it up in my Room
at once a proof of your Friendship & of your Brother's taste - - -
I am much obliged to you for the receipt you sent me; the complaint
is not at all in the eye, but in the ciliary glands: Sea-bathing will be
most likely to remove it: & I shall go to the Sea next week. Summer
Time, Nature & Exercise will I hope finally relieve me; but at
present I must, and I flatter myself I do, submit to irremidi-
-able irremediable evil, with patience; I suffer no pain - You do me
injustice, my dear, in reproaching me with not taking ex-
-ercise exercise , I said I was not fond of it, but I assure you I walk an hour
every day even in this cold Weather - Art & Medicine have
tried their skill with me in vain, Nature & Exercise shall
now have fair play - I am afraid you had a great deal
of trouble about the franks: I hope you will never delay writing
to me for want of them, for I assure you I do not think the plea-
-sure pleasure your letters give me too dearly purchased without them

My dear Fanny I was just going to conclude this long letter
when I recollected, what I certainly ought & should have recollected
sooner, if I had, had less dependance on your good temper; viz, that
I have been nearly a month in answering your last - I shall
surprize you perhaps when I tell you that I actually began to
write to you the very day I received your's but I have never
had time to finish my letter - Not time! - - - - Why indeed you may
well be a little surprized, & I find that at last I must tell you
what I am about; in my own defence; well then, I am writing
a book. - - - A Book! - - - yes a book & in six volumes; I began it
a month ago & I have written 2 volumes: but I will neither tell you
the title or the subject of it, till it is published & has been reviewed
& then I will send you a set of the if it succeeds, but I dare not
expose myself so far as to tell you beforehand, least it should not
succeed; I suppose it will be published before the end of next
Summer; I am not certain yet whether it will be bound in three
octavo or six duedicimo volumes - You may assure yourself
my dear friend that I will not forget to send them you, indeed
I am ashamed not already to have sent you something by way
of acknowledgement, if not of equivalent to, your pretty drawings -
But you will say "What excuse can your writing a book be for ne-
-glecting neglecting to answer your friend's letter? - - - I will tell you; my
father is in now in Dublin, & he has an opportunity of sending
the volume (or volumes if they are published in Duedissimo) over to
Eng-
-land England
to be printed this week, therefore I was very desirous to
have them finished; the very day I had finished them I open-
-ed opened my writing desk to look for the letter I had began to write to
you; on reading it over, I found it was such a charming con-
fusion confusion of Nonsense that I was under a necessity of beginning
it again - I had always had recourse to it as a species of relaxation
when my head ached & when I had written till I hardly knew
one letter from another - You ask me if I have read Cecilia? |
No I have not: & from what you say of it I am not at all desirous to
read it though a lady in the Neighbourhood has promised to send it
me. I assure you I have not opened a book this month, though I
have been tempted alternately by Gibbons,
Bielfied Bielfeld
and Bacon
so you see I have been seriously at Work - & except a pamphlet of
Mrs. Day's I have not read a pamphlet either - at this very time
I am writing to you, I have that famous Epic-poem the Luciad
lying beside me unopened - Now we are on the Subject of
Books my dear Fanny, I must remember to beg you will let
me know in your next your opinion of Mr. Ameci's book, what
the Subject of it is? & where it may be had? for I left London the
morning after I saw you in Wimpole Street & I have never
been able to see it - You ask me what Market Town, Edgeworth's
town is near, it is itself a Market town & you will find it in the old
Maps of Ireland under the name of Mastrim - it is near
Mul-
-lingar Mullingar
, Longford, Athlone & Granard - - Pray my dear, in
yr0. next send me a little plan of your house & improvements at
Cranford & though I am no Drawer as you know, I will endeavor
to give you in return some confused idea of this Place -
If it is out of compliment you write to me always on such
pretty little sheets of gilt paper, I will very readily dispense
with them, for my part I like better to converse with you
than to compliment you - Remember me always when you
write to any of our friends in Wimpole Street, in the kindest man
-ner manner to them. Miss Van, once intimated to me, that she thought
I had a particular turn for ridicule & seemed to think that
I should indulge it at the expense of others - you may, nay I
would wish you to shew her any of my letters or all of them, to
convince her that she has been mistaken - in a child such
a failing is excusable, but if time & reflexion do not cure it
it leads to debases, perhaps vitiates the heart, by render-
-ing rendering it susceptible of pleasure at the uneasiness of Other's -
I should be sorry that Miss Van therefore was not devabusie
on this head - - - - - - - - - -

Adieu, the length of your letter my dear Miss Robinson
convinces me that you are not tired with mine - But seri
-ously seriously will you forgive me for my neglect in not writing
to you sooner? a . . . you smile. . . . Well then as it is my
first offence I hope I may be allowed the Benefit of the Cler
gy Clergy . . . I refer my case not to your Justice, but to your Mercy -
